Context:
Program Name: RPN Bridge to BScN
Code: S442
Credential: Ontario College Graduate Certificate
Duration: 2 semesters
Starting Months: September
Domestic Tuition: $6,773.00
Centre: Health Sciences
School: Sally Horsfall Eaton School of Nursing
Location: Waterfront Campus
Method of Study: Full-time
Experiential Learning: Clinical Placement
Delivery Mode: Hybrid (Fall 2023, Semester 1) and Other (Winter 2024, Semester 2)
Program Availability:
- Fall 2023: Closed for domestic students and not available for international students.
- Winter 2024: Not Available for domestic or international students.
- Spring 2024: Not Available for both domestic and international students.
Related Programs: Practical Nursing (PN) (S121), Bachelor of Science in Nursing (B.Sc.N.) (S118), Personal Support Worker Pathway to Practical Nursing (S119).
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/RPN Bridge to BScN Program (Postgraduate) S442 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context: The RPN Bridge program is offered at the Daphne Cockwell Centre for Health Sciences located at the Waterfront Campus. The program is delivered in a hybrid format with both in-class and online learning, and semesters are delivered consecutively starting in September and January. Clinical placements will take place during semester 2, in either a simulated clinical environment or within a healthcare organization. Students are expected to attend their placement each week. The clinical placements may only be approved for students who are fully vaccinated against COVID-19. Students who successfully complete the RPN Bridge to B.Sc.N. Bridge program will be eligible to apply to Trent University’s post-bridge nursing degree program, which is delivered on-site at George Brown College's Daphne Cockwell Centre for Health Sciences. To be eligible for admission to Trent University’s Post-Bridge B.Sc.N. Pathway, students must have met the Bridge program admission criteria and graduated from the approved RPN Bridge to B.Sc.N. certificate program with a minimum cumulative program average grade of 75% and not less than 70% in any course for which advanced standing credit is assigned by Trent University. The post-bridge program at Trent University consists of 20 credits.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/RPN Bridge to BScN Program (Postgraduate) S442 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context: The Trent Post-Bridge B.Sc.N. program consists of 20 credits and takes five consecutive semesters for full-time students (19 months) or eight consecutive semesters for part-time students to complete. Students are required to take specific courses each semester, including NURS 1093 - Becoming an Ethical Practitioner, NURS 1095 - Nursing Informatics in the Health-Care Information Age, and others. The program aims to help graduates communicate effectively, collaborate with interprofessional teams, integrate information technology, demonstrate social responsibility, and apply theoretical knowledge, among other skills and competencies. The tuition for domestic students is $6 [amount possibly incomplete]. For more details about the Trent Post-Bridge B.Sc.N. program, visit Trent's website.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/RPN Bridge to BScN Program (Postgraduate) S442 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
Program: Registered Nursing (RPN) at George Brown College
Tuition & Fees:
- Domestic tuition: $6,773.00 for the first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2022
Financial Assistance: Approved for OSAP funding for applicants who meet eligibility criteria
Admission Requirements:
- In good standing with the College of Nurses of Ontario and without practice restrictions
- Graduation from a two-year community college Practical Nursing (PN) diploma program in Ontario with a minimum cumulative program average of 75% and no failed or repeated courses
Additional Admission Requirements:
- Submission of all post-secondary transcripts
- Minimum combined grade point average (CGPA) of 2.33 (C+) for applicants with prior university or college study outside Practical Nursing
- Course-by-course evaluation from WES or ICAS for international students
- Letter indicating a minimum passing score for PASS/FAIL grades or letter from issuing academic institution for applicants with foreign education
Admission Consideration: Applicants with prior nursing studies in Bachelor of Nursing or Bridging program will be considered on a case-by-case basis
Additional Information: Program information is subject to change without notice. Students are responsible for verifying George Brown College fee requirements. This program is open to domestic applicants only.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/RPN Bridge to BScN Program (Postgraduate) S442 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
* The admissions committee for this program is composed of representatives from Trent University and George Brown College.
* All applicants offered admission require the approval of the admissions committee.
* Applicants will undergo a detailed evaluation of core course performance and competencies for transfer of credit evaluation.
* Applicants who have been absent from full-time formal Practical Nursing, Bridging or BScN education for a period of 10 years will be considered on a case-by-case basis.
* This program is open to domestic applicants only.
* Before commencing the clinical practice course, students must successfully complete an approved CPR course (BCLS – HCP Level) and a Standard First Aid Certificate course annually.
* Applicants should review the requisite skills for nurses listed on the College of Nurses of Ontario website.
* Upon acceptance into this program, students must meet and complete all mandatory pre-placement requirements within 10 to 12 weeks.
* Students must provide proof of medical records (such as MMR, Varicella, Hep B blood test reports/titres, Tdap shot valid every 10 years, Two Step TB Skin Test), a clear Police Vulnerable Sector Check renewed every year, CPR level HCP renewed annually, annual flu shot, and mask fit test renewed every two years.
* The clinical placement agencies may have additional requirements due to the pandemic.
* Students who do not comply with these requirements will not be eligible to attend the practice area.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/RPN Bridge to BScN Program (Postgraduate) S442 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context: Students are required to comply with the health policy and non-academic requirements of the clinical practicum program, submit all required documentation by deadlines, and have a Police Vulnerable Sector Check completed and renewed annually. The health form and information on the check process can be found on the Pre-placement website. The fees for the police record check vary. Students who do not meet these requirements may be excluded from clinical placements and jeopardize their academic standing and program completion. Failure to provide a clear Police Vulnerable Sector Check may prevent students from starting field or clinical placements, which could hinder their progress in the program. Clinical agency partners require students to be fully vaccinated against COVID-19 for approval of clinical placements within their facilities; students who are not vaccinated risk being unable to complete the program and/or secure employment.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/RPN Bridge to BScN Program (Postgraduate) S442 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
George Brown College offers the following programs related to nursing:
1. Practical Nursing (PN) (S121)
2. Bachelor of Science in Nursing (B.Sc.N.) (S118)
3. Personal Support Worker Pathway to Practical Nursing (S119)

Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges. For more information, contact the Sally Horsfall Eaton School of Nursing at 416-415-5000, ext. 2367 or email nursing@georgebrown.ca. The college has a Contact Centre that can be reached at 416-415-2000 (TTY 1-877-515-5559) or long distance 1-800-265-2002.

An individual named Anshumi Joshi shared her experience at George Brown College, starting with the Personal Support Worker program and then completing the Practical Nursing Program and the Bridge to BScN program. She is now entering the Trent University BScN program at the George Brown College site. During her time at George Brown College, she worked as a peer leader with the Student Success Program and later as a tutor with Accessibility Services. She expressed gratitude for the support she received from faculty and student services staff, and made lifelong nursing friendships.

To apply or learn more about programs and life at George Brown College, visitors can book campus tours, info sessions, and sign up to receive tailored resources.
